title: STUDY THEME,  The Humanity of Jesus. Part 27
devotional:
To be truly human is not to allow the inevitable injustice of life to define us.

No matter who we are, we’ve all got baggage, we’ve all felt pain, rejection and disappointment to a greater or lesser degree. It is very easy for anyone of us to cultivate and develop a victim mindset; we can allow the experiences of injustices of the past to shape us.

The injustices and cruelty Jesus experienced through his death on the cross did not turn him into an angry bitter person, but through His resurrection, he experienced freedom and victory that only God could give. Often emotionally, we remain in the grave, we have been badly hurt, abused, disappointed, and part of us dies. We try our best to live with the pain, keeping it buried, keeping it under control, allowing its nagging influence to insidiously and slowly poison our hearts and warp our thinking. The power of the resurrection can deliver us from the self-destructive attitudes that can be concealed in the baggage of our past. All of us have come through times of difficulty, we have all known times of suffering and tragedy, but the pain of the past does not have to define us in the present.

In his humanity Jesus chose to have the mindset that was free from the entrapment of victimhood.

Let me just pause here for a moment and ask the question, do you live as a victim? People with a victim mentality do not have the ability to build real relationships. Jesus was victimised, but he refused to be a victim. He rose from the dead, and as evidence of the power of God in his life he refused to live as a victim.

What are the possible evidences of living out of a victim mentality?

a. You don’t want to accept responsibility – You will do anything to absolve him/herself from personal responsibility for any aspect of their lives.

b. You become withdrawn. If you weren’t someone who liked staying away from others and you find yourself suddenly wanting to be by yourself, then you may be a victim.

c. You see yourself as a failure. When you start seeing yourself as a failure then you may be a victim.

d. You are not able to forgive. If you are not able to forgive all those who have hurt or harmed you including yourself, then you may be a victim.

e. You have become angry and bitter. If you find that you are becoming angry and bitter, it means you may be a victim
prayer: Prayer, Father thank you I don’t need to live with a victim mindset.
